en_first_half: The evening passed off in the equal indulgence of feeling. She played over every favourite song that she had been used to play to Willoughby, every air in which their voices had been oftenest joined, and sat at the instrument gazing on every line of music that he had written out for her, till her heart was so heavy that no farther sadness could be
en_second_half: gained; and this nourishment of grief was every day applied. She spent whole hours at the pianoforte alternately singing and crying; her voice often totally suspended by her tears. In books too, as well as in music, she courted the misery which a contrast between the past and present was certain of giving. She read nothing but what they had been used to read together.
en_results: borne. The music, which had once been a source of such joy and companionship, now served only to remind her of the emptiness that had been left by his departure. She felt as though she was wandering through a desolate landscape, with no direction or purpose, and the only sound that broke the silence was the faint echo of his voice, whispering her name in her mind. The
en_results_raw: be borne. The music, which had once been a source of such joy and companionship, now served only to remind her of the emptiness that had been left by his departure. She felt as though she was wandering through a desolate landscape, with no direction or purpose, and the only sound that broke the silence was the faint echo of his voice, whispering her name in her mind. The room, which had once been filled with the warmth and laughter of their time together, now seemed cold and unforgiving, a constant reminder of all that she had lost. As the night wore on, she found herself becoming increasingly withdrawn, her thoughts consumed by the memories of their time together, and the what-ifs that haunted her every waking moment. The music, which had once been a source of such happiness, now seemed to mock her, a cruel reminder of all that she had been denied, and all that she would never have again.

Cô nhớ lại những lần họ đi dạo cùng nhau dưới ánh trăng, những lần họ ngồi bên nhau trên bãi biển, những lần họ ôm nhau và nói những lời ngọt ngào. Cô nhớ lại từng chi tiết nhỏ nhất của những khoảnh khắc đó, từng nốt nhạc, từng từ ngữ, từng ánh mắt. Cô cảm thấy như thể cô đang sống lại những khoảnh khắc đó, như thể cô đang được quay trở lại thời điểm mà tình yêu của họ còn tươi đẹp và mãnh liệt. Nhưng rồi, cô lại trở về với hiện thực, với sự thật rằng Willoughby đã đi, và cô lại phải đối mặt với một thế giới mà không có anh ấy. Cô cảm thấy như thể cô đang bị chia cắt khỏi một phần của chính mình, như thể cô đang bị mất đi một phần của tâm hồn. Cô không biết làm thế nào để vượt qua được nỗi đau này, nhưng cô biết rằng cô phải cố gắng, phải tìm cách để sống tiếp, để tiếp tục yêu, để tiếp tục sống.
es_first_half: La tarde transcurrió en igual abandono a los sentimientos. Volvió a tocar cada una de las canciones que le gustaban y que solía tocar para Willoughby, cada aire en el que con más frecuencia se habían unido sus voces, y permaneció sentada ante el instrumento contemplando cada línea de música que él había copiado para ella, hasta que fue tan grande el pesar de su corazón que ya no podía
es_second_half: alcanzarse tristeza mayor; y día a día se esforzó en nutrir así su dolor. Pasaba horas completas al piano alternando cantos y llantos, a menudo con la voz totalmente ahogada por las lágrimas. También en los libros, al igual que en la música, cortejaba la desdicha que con toda certeza podía obtener de la confrontación entre el pasado y el presente. No leía nada sino lo que solían leer juntos.

Se acercó a la ventana y miró hacia afuera, intentando encontrar algo de consuelo en la belleza del
es_results_raw: contener las lágrimas que brotaban de sus ojos, y se levantó de la silla con la intención de alejarse de allí, pero la vista de la habitación la detuvo, recordándole a cada objeto que había sido testigo de su felicidad con Willoughby, y su corazón se llenó de un dolor que parecía no tener fin. Se acercó a la ventana y miró hacia afuera, intentando encontrar algo de consuelo en la belleza del paisaje, pero todo parecía sombrío y triste, reflejando el estado de su alma. La noche comenzaba a caer y la habitación se estaba volviendo cada vez más oscura, pero ella no se daba cuenta, tan absorta estaba en sus pensamientos. De repente, escuchó un ruido detrás de ella y se dio la vuelta, esperando ver a alguien, pero la habitación estaba vacía. La música que había estado tocando en su mente se detuvo abruptamente y se quedó en silencio, como si la presencia de Willoughby hubiera sido la única cosa que la mantenía viva. La oscuridad parecía cerrarse a su alrededor, y ella se sintió sola y desamparada, sin saber qué hacer para llenar el vacío que había dejado su ausencia.

I am not afraid of being thought to talk nonsense, when I say that I have often felt the most exquisite pleasure in a walk among the woods and fields, when I have been entirely alone, and when I have not been thinking of the beauty of the scene. It is a pleasure which I have found to be quite independent of the power of describing it, and which I have often felt when I have been unable to express it in words. I am not one of those people who can talk of the beauty of a landscape, and of the various effects of light and shadow, and of the different kinds of trees and flowers, and of the various moods of the sky, and so on, with the ease and fluency of a professional describer. My feelings are not of that sort; they are much more simple and sincere, and I am afraid they may be thought very common and unrefined. But I do not care; for I know that they are genuine, and that they are the result of a real and strong feeling of the beauty of nature, which I have experienced in many different places, and under many different circumstances. I have walked through the woods on a summer's day, when the sun was shining brightly through the trees, and the birds were singing in the branches above me; I have walked through the fields on a autumnal evening, when the sun was setting behind the hills, and the air was filled with the scent of ripe corn; and I have walked through the snow-covered woods on a winter's day, when the trees were bare and the ground was white, and the only sound was the crunching of the snow under my feet. And in all these different scenes, I have felt the same pleasure, the same sense of delight and wonder, which I have felt in none of the more artificial and conventional scenes which I have seen in the company of others. It is a pleasure which I think is worth having, and which I hope to continue to experience, as long as I live.

es_results_raw: beauty de la naturaleza, pero en realidad no saben qué es lo que están describiendo. La gente se ha vuelto tan superficial en su admiración que ya no se detiene a reflexionar sobre la verdadera esencia de lo que ven. La naturaleza es algo más que un simple espectáculo para los ojos, es una fuente de inspiración, de sabiduría y de conexión con lo divino. Pero ¿quién se detiene a apreciarla de verdad? ¿Quién se toma el tiempo de escuchar su lenguaje silencioso, de sentir su energía vital y de aprender de su sabiduría ancestral? La admiración por la naturaleza ha sido reducida a una mera moda, a una tendencia que se sigue sin reflexión ni profundidad. Pero yo creo que todavía hay personas que sienten el llamado de la naturaleza, que la aman con pasión y la respetan con devoción. Son aquellos que se detienen a contemplar el atardecer, a escuchar el canto de los pájaros, a sentir la brisa en su rostro y a sentirse parte de algo mucho mayor que ellos mismos. Son aquellos que saben que la naturaleza es un reflejo de nuestra propia alma, y que en su belleza y su complejidad se esconde un mensaje profundo que nos invita a reflexionar sobre nuestra propia existencia.

His wife, however, was a woman of a very different character, and her silly behaviour was not the only thing that made her disagreeable. She was also very vain and self-important, and seemed to think herself of much greater consequence than she really was. Elinor could not help laughing at the absurdity of her behaviour, and she was surprised that her husband did not see it, or at least that he did not endeavour to check it. She began to think that he was not so much to blame for his wife's behaviour as she had at first supposed, and that he was perhaps as much a sufferer by her folly as any one else. She was also struck by the difference between his manner towards his wife and his manner towards herself, and she could not help feeling a little pleased that he seemed to treat her with more respect and consideration than he did his own wife. She was not, however, going to let her feelings get the better of her, and she determined to be on her guard against any foolish notions that might arise from this circumstance. She knew that she was not in a position to judge of his character, and that she must not allow herself to be influenced by her own feelings, but must rather endeavour to form a just and impartial opinion of him. She therefore resolved to observe him more closely, and to try to discover the real character of the man, and not to be swayed by his outward appearance or his behaviour towards his wife.

en_first_half: "His character is now before you; expensive, dissipated, and worse than both. Knowing all this, as I have now known it many weeks, guess what I must have felt on seeing your sister as fond of him as ever, and on being assured that she was to marry him: guess what I must have felt for all your sakes. When I came to you last week and found you alone, I came determined to know the truth; though irresolute what to do when it WAS known. My behaviour must have seemed strange to you then; but now you will comprehend it. To suffer you all to be so deceived; to see your sister—but what could I do? I had no hope of interfering with success; and sometimes I thought your sister's influence might yet reclaim him. But now, after such dishonorable usage, who can tell what were his designs on her. Whatever they may have been, however, she may now, and hereafter doubtless WILL turn with gratitude towards her own condition, when she compares it with that of
en_second_half: my poor Eliza, when she considers the wretched and hopeless situation of this poor girl, and pictures her to herself, with an affection for him so strong, still as strong as her own, and with a mind tormented by self–reproach, which must attend her through life. Surely this comparison must have its use with her. She will feel her own sufferings to be nothing. They proceed from no misconduct, and can bring no disgrace. On the contrary, every friend must be made still more her friend by them. Concern for her unhappiness, and respect for her fortitude under it, must strengthen every attachment. Use your own discretion, however, in communicating to her what I have told you. You must know best what will be its effect; but had I not seriously, and from my heart believed it might be of service, might lessen her regrets, I would not have suffered myself to trouble you with this account of my family afflictions, with a recital which may seem to have been intended to raise myself at the expense of others."

vi_first_half: - Tư cách của anh giờ được đặt trước mặt cô - xa hoa, phóng đãng, và còn tệ hại hơn cả hai. Khi đã biết được tất cả - vì tôi đã biết được nhiều tuần rồi - cô thử đoán tôi đã nghĩ gì khi nhìn thấy em gái cô vẫn thân ái với anh ấy như bao giờ; và khi được tin em gái cô sẽ cưới anh ấy, thử đoán tôi đã nghĩ gì cho cô ấy. "Tuần rồi khi tôi đến đây và thấy cô chỉ có một mình, tôi đến với chủ định tìm hiểu sự thật; tuy không rõ mình sẽ làm gì một khi đã biết sự thật đau lòng. Lúc ấy cử chỉ của tôi hẳn là kỳ lạ đối với cô, nhưng bây giờ cô đã hiểu tại sao. Làm cho hai cô đau khổ thấy bị lừa dối như thế; thấy em gái cô... nhưng tôi làm gì được? Tôi không hy vọng ngăn cản được cuộc hôn nhân, và đôi lúc tôi nghĩ ảnh hưởng của em gái cô sẽ cảm hóa được anh ta." "Nhưng bây giờ, sau những sự lợi dụng ô nhục như thế, ai mà nói được anh toan tính những gì với em gái cô. Mi comportamiento debe haberle extrañado, pero ahora lo entenderá. Tener que verlas a todas ustedes engañadas en esa forma; ver a su hermana... pero, ¿qué podía hacer? But now I find that she was only being polite, and that she has been making a fool of me all along. I am so vexed and disappointed, and I do not know what to do. I shall have to be more careful in the future, and not be so easily deceived by appearances. I shall have to be more discerning, and not be so quick to trust people. en_first_half: "Yes; once, while she was staying in this house, I happened to drop in for ten minutes; and I saw quite enough of her. The merest awkward country girl, without style, or elegance, and almost without beauty.— I remember her perfectly. Just the kind of girl I should suppose likely to captivate poor Edward. I offered immediately, as soon as my mother related the affair to me, to talk to him myself, and dissuade him from the match; but it was too late THEN, I found, to do any thing, for unluckily, I was not in the way at first, and knew nothing of it till after the
en_second_half: breach had taken place, when it was not for me, you know, to interfere. But had I been informed of it a few hours earlier—I think it is most probable—that something might have been hit on. I certainly should have represented it to Edward in a very strong light. 'My dear fellow,' I should have said, 'consider what you are doing. You are making a most disgraceful connection, and such a one as your family are unanimous in disapproving.' I cannot help thinking, in short, that means might have been found. But now it is all too late. He must be starved, you know;—that is certain; absolutely starved."
